alaska-measure-1.title: Measure 1
alaska-measure-1.name: Voter Registration Amendment
alaska-measure-1.description:
In Alaska, virtually everyone who is eligible to vote applies for a dividend from the “oil fund.” Measure 1 would automatically (unless they opt out) register to vote anyone who applies for the dividend and, by linking the two actions, register as many as 50,000 additional voters, many of them Native Alaskans. 

We need higher turnout and more Native and minority voices in our politics, but for too long voter registration has been an obstacle. Measure 1 would be a big leap forward.

california-prop-61.title: Proposition 61
california-prop-61.name: Drug Price Standards
california-prop-61.description:
The future of prescription drug costs in America comes down to this: Do we have the guts to stand up to drug companies who are ripping us off? 

Proposition 61 would require that the State of California pay no more for prescription drugs than what’s paid for by the U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs, which is allowed to negotiate drug prices. This initiative would save California taxpayers billions of dollars and open the floodgates to similar initiatives around the country—and Big Pharma knows it. 

Big drug companies plan to spend $100 million in misleading ads to defeat this measure, because it would put a serious dent in their price gouging. The fact is, for years, drug companies have been more focused on making huge profits than on developing new medication, which is why they spend far more on marketing than research—expenses that they pass on directly to consumers and taxpayers. 

So far, elected officials have been unable or unwilling to take action to lower drug costs. Proposition 61 lets the people of California do it themselves.

california-prop-59.title: Proposition 59
california-prop-59.name: Overturn of Citizens United Act
california-prop-59.description:
The Citizens United Supreme Court decision, which opened the doors to unlimited corporate spending in our elections, was a major blow to our democracy. 

Proposition 59 would propose that California’s elected officials use all of their authority to propose and ratify an amendment to the federal Constitution to overturn Citizens United. It also suggests that the constitutional amendment should clarify that corporations should not have the same constitutional rights as human beings. 

A Yes vote on Proposition 59 will restore a government of the people, by the people, and for the people!

california-prop-62.title: Proposition 62
california-prop-62.name: Repeal of the Death Penalty Initiative
california-prop-62.description:
Since 1978, California taxpayers have paid $5 billion to maintain the death penalty and death row, and executed 13 people. That’s an average cost of more than $384 million per execution.

Proposition 62 replaces a failed death penalty system with a strict life sentence, work and restitution – saving taxpayers $150 million per year. It also guarantees California never executes an innocent person.

colorado-amendment-69.title: Amendment 69
colorado-amendment-69.name: ColoradoCare
colorado-amendment-69.description:
Amendment 69, also known as ColoradoCare, would bring one of Bernie Sanders’ major policy proposals, Medicare-for-all universal health care, to the state of Colorado. 

Health care is a human right, and a Medicare-for-all system would provide quality health care to every resident while still costing less than the current system. ColoradoCare gets rid of the bureaucracy as well as marketing costs that drive up private health insurance premiums, and it takes the burden off of small businesses to cover climbing health care costs. 

Every other major country has sometype of  universal health care system, and ColoradoCare would lead the nation in proving that Medicare-for-all is the humane and cost-efficient solution to health care coverage.

maryland-citizens-election-fund.title: A
maryland-citizens-election-fund.name: Howard County Citizens' Election Fund
maryland-citizens-election-fund.description:
Running for office shouldn’t require begging the rich and powerful for donations—that’s why we need to move toward the public funding of elections. 

The residents of Howard County, Maryland are on the verge of creating a Citizens’ Election Fund, which would match small donations and require participating candidates to reject large or corporate donations. It encourages more people to participate in the election process and allows candidates to be judged on the strength of their ideas, not their willingness to please the ruling class.

oregon-measure-97.title: Measure 97
oregon-measure-97.name: Oregon Business Tax Increase Initiative
oregon-measure-97.description:
Measure 97, the Oregon Business Tax Increase Initiative, would increase the minimum corporate tax on corporations making over $25 million in a year. 

With the revenue Measure 97 would raise, Oregon could hire 7,500 new teachers, provide quality in-home care to 20,000 seniors, or make health care more affordable by decreasing out-of-pocket expenses. Measure 97 holds big corporations accountable for paying their fair share to build a better society for everyone.

washington-initiative-735.title: Initiative 735
washington-initiative-735.name: Restoring the Voice of We the People
washington-initiative-735.description:
To restore our one person-one vote democracy, we must pass a constitutional amendment to overturn Citizens United. 

Initiative 735 would urge the Washington state congressional delegation to propose an amendment to the federal Constitution which would clarify that constitutional rights belong only to individuals, not corporations, and that constitutionally-protected free speech excludes the spending of money.

alabama-amendment-8.title: Amendment 8
alabama-amendment-8.name: Constitutionalize Right-To-Work Laws
alabama-amendment-8.description:
Alabama is currently governed by right-to-work laws, which are designed to weaken unions and thus lower worker wages. The entire purpose of Amendment 8 is to enshrine these laws in the Alabama state constitution, thus making them harder to change down the line. 

This amendment is an attempt to legislate through the state constitution. Instead of allowing legislators to defend and debate their position, it needlessly codifies current statutes and limits the government’s ability to make timely alterations to the law, or modifications that reflect the will of the people. 

Studies have shown that as unions become weaker, wages drop for all workers—even those not in a union. If we believe in workers' rights, we must believe that our job is to make it easier, not harder, for workers to join a union. And that means we must work to stop Amendment 8.

arkansas-issue-7.title: Issue 7
arkansas-issue-7.name: Medical Cannabis Statute
arkansas-issue-7.description:
Arkansas Issue 7, the Medical Cannabis Statute, would legalize medical marijuana in the state of Arkansas. 

National polls show that more than 80 percent of Americans support legalizing medical marijuana, and a majority of doctors agree. Patients suffering with HIV/AIDS, glaucoma, cancer and chemotherapy, multiple sclerosis, epilepsy, and other illnesses find that cannabis relieves their symptoms—sometimes when nothing else will.

It is time for common sense and compassion to prevail. It's time to legalize medical marijuana in Arkansas and in every state.

california-prop-64.title: Proposition 64
california-prop-64.name: Adult Use of Marijuana Act
california-prop-64.description:
Proposition 64, the Adult Use of Marijuana Act, would allow adults 21 years old or older to possess and use marijuana for recreational purposes. Revenue from taxes on marijuana cultivate and retail would be spent on drug research, youth programs and more.

As legalization of marijuana in other states has shown, allowing for marijuana use among adults in a safe, legal and taxed environment is far more advantageous than the failed “War on Drugs” approach of past decades. Proposition 64 would allow responsible use of marijuana by adults while protecting children, and it would also create a new tax revenue stream to fund public health and safety programs.

california-prop-66.title: Proposition 66
california-prop-66.name: Death Penalty Procedures Initiative
california-prop-66.description:
Not only is the death penalty a burden on taxpayers, but too many innocent people have been executed when they were not guilty.  Proposition 66 would recklessly alter the process to challenge death penalty convictions by limiting the ability to present new evidence of innocence. 

Proposition 66 would be a reckless experiment.  The death penalty needs to be repealed, not altered in ways that increase the risk of executing innocent people.

california-prop-58.title: Proposition 58
california-prop-58.name: Non-English Languages Allowed in Public Education Act
california-prop-58.description: Because of an outdated 20-year old law, California schools are restricted to English-only instructional methods. Prop 58 would update that law to make sure all California students are given the opportunity to learn English in the most effective method possible.  It also encourages programs for native English users to become proficient in a second language.

california-prop-67.title: Proposition 67
california-prop-67.name: Plastic Bag Ban Veto Referendum
california-prop-67.description:
Proposition 67 would prohibit large grocery stores grocery and other stores from providing customers single–use plastic or paper carryout bags but would permit sale of recycled paper bags and reusable bags. A wide variety of environmental groups, public officials, unions and city governments have endorsed Proposition 67 bedause the ban will protect oceans and wildlife while also reducing clean-up costs. 

Who opposes Prop 67? Four out-of-state plastic bag companies have formed a coalition to defeat it in order to protect their own profits.  Out-of-state corporations shouldn’t decide California’s laws—the people of California deserve to have a law that works for them.

florida-amendment-2.title: Amendment 2
florida-amendment-2.name: Medical Marijuana Legalization Initiative
florida-amendment-2.description:
Amendment 2, the Florida Medical Marijuana Legalization Initiative, would allow licensed state physicians to prescribe medical marijuana to individuals with specific debilitating diseases. 

Patients who gain relief through cannabis use, especially the terminally ill, shouldn’t have to choose between treatment and breaking the law. Medical cannabis is vitally important to thousands of Floridians—help them by passing medical cannabis in Florida.

louisiana-amendment-2.title: Amendment 2
louisiana-amendment-2.name: Authorize College Boards to Establish Tuition and Fees
louisiana-amendment-2.description:
Amendment 2 would allow college boards to establish tuition and fee amounts for Louisiana public colleges and universities without legislative approval. That’s absurd. Louisiana voters fund the state’s public college and university system with their tax dollars, and like residents of every other state, they deserve to have a say in tuition and fee costs. 

In the last year alone, Louisiana public universities raised tuition and fee amounts by as much as 5 percent. At a time when public colleges are increasingly unaffordable, it makes no sense to allow college boards to raise tuition and fee amounts with no accountability to Louisiana residents.

maine-question-1.title: Question 1
maine-question-1.name: Maine Marijuana Legalization Measure
maine-question-1.description:
Question 1, also known as the Maine Marijuana Legalization Measure, would legalize recreational marijuana for adults over the age of 21. 

Allowing adult marijuana use in a safe, legal and taxed environment produces far better outcomes than criminalization. It truly makes no sense that a teenager getting caught smoking marijuana gets a criminal record when we fail to prosecute bankers who wrecked our economy. 

A Yes on Question 1 to legalize and tax marijuana will make Maine safer while bolstering the economy.

maine-question-4.title: Question 4
maine-question-4.name: Maine Minimum Wage Increase
maine-question-4.description:
Question 4, the Maine Minimum Wage Increase, would gradually increase the state’s minimum wage to $12 by 2020 with annual cost-of-living increases thereafter.

This progressive step forward will enable many workers to achieve a middle-class life rather than being stuck in poverty, and it will also help local business as more workers will have the income to go out to purchase goods and services. Recent studies show that states that raise the minimum wage see faster job growth as a result. 
 
The truth is Maine’s current minimum wage of $7.50 an hour is a starvation wage.  Question 4 would lift thousands of Maine workers out of poverty and give working families a shot at a middle class life.

maine-question-5.title: Question 5
maine-question-5.name: Ranked Choice Voting
maine-question-5.description:
Ranked choice voting (RCV) allows voters to rank candidates in order of choice. Candidates do best when they attract a strong core of first-choice support while also reaching out for second and even third choices.

We as voters shouldn’t be forced to vote for “the lesser of two evils.” Ranked choice voting will result in less negative campaigning and forces candidates to reach out beyond a narrow spectrum of voters in order to win. 

Ultimately, RCV  results in fairer representation of voters and a more robust democracy. While it’s been utilized at the local level in cities around the country, Maine would be the first state to adopt RCV.

massachusetts-measure-2.title: Measure 2
massachusetts-measure-2.name: Charter School Expansion
massachusetts-measure-2.description:
Under Massachusetts' current funding structure, Measure 2 for Charter School Expansion would siphon money away from traditional public schools, including schools in low-income communities. 

As Sen. Elizabeth Warren said when she spoke out against Measure 2, education must be about providing for all of our children, not leaving many behind.

missouri-amendment-6.title: Amendment 6
missouri-amendment-6.name: Voter ID Requirement
missouri-amendment-6.description:
Amendment 6 would amend Missouri's state constitution to require a state-issued photo ID in order to vote. As with similar voter suppression measures around the country, this one is backed by Republican state legislators with the hope of disenfranchising up to 200,000 Missouri voters. Those voters include many eligible voters who are less likely to get a drivers license like students, poor people and people of color. It also includes veterans, as a veterans ID would not count for the purpose fo voting. 

The reality is we have virtually no voter fraud in America. Missouri has had just 2 cases of voter fraud in the last 7 years. What is the fraud is that Republican legislators, in order to help their chances at the polls, are changing laws that disenfranchise thousands of voters. 

Measures like Amendment 6 have no place in our democracy.

montana-initiative-177.title: Initiative 177
montana-initiative-177.name: Animal Trap Restrictions Initiative
montana-initiative-177.description:
Initiative 177 (I-177), the Montana Animal Trap Restrictions Initiative, would prohibit individuals from using animal traps and snares on state public lands. Hidden traps and snares are a year-round threat to people who work and recreate on public lands. Their very presence limits the right of others to feel safe in lands that are maintained by taxpayers and intended for use by all citizens. 

Additionally, trapping results in kills that are neither quick nor efficient. Animals, panicked and in enormous pain, frequently chew off their own limbs to get away. It’s a cruel and wasteful method and an inappropriate use of public resources.

montana-initiative-182.title: Initiative 182
montana-initiative-182.name: Medical Marijuana Initiative
montana-initiative-182.description:
Initiative 182 (I-182), the Medical Marijuana Initiative, would repeal the medical marijuana three-patient limit for providers. 

Montana voters overwhelmingly approved medical marijuana in 2004, but the state legislature repealed the law soon after and replaced it with a much more restrictive and unworkable law. I-182 will ensure safe and legal access for patients through greater accountability for providers and the removal of the three person patient limit.

nebraska-bill-268.title: Legislative Bill 268
nebraska-bill-268.name: Eliminate Death Penalty
nebraska-bill-268.description:
In 2015, fiscal conservatives, the religious community and Nebraskans from across the political spectrum came together to pass Legislative Bill 268 (LB 268), which eliminated the death penalty. Now, a conservative millionaire governor whose family spent hundreds of thousands of dollars lobbying against LB 268 is hoping to repeal the bill. 

Voting to Retain LB 268 will send a clear message: The death penalty is a burden on taxpayers, serves no effective deterrent to criminals and has no place in Nebraska. It’s time to move forward with smart alternatives that prioritize public safety.

nevada-question-2.title: Question 2
nevada-question-2.name: Nevada Marijuana Legalization Initiative
nevada-question-2.description:
Question 2, the Nevada Marijuana Legalization Initiative, would legalize one ounce or less of marijuana for recreational use for adults 21 years of age and over. The new excise tax revenue from the sale of marijuana would be spent on schools. 

The criminalization of marijuana has been a disaster, particularly for communities of color. The truth is that marijuana is not any riskier or unhealthier than tobacco and alcohol and should be legalized, regulated and taxed just the same. 

As other states that have legalized marijuana have led the way in showing us, regulation and taxation of marijuana is the safe and responsible policy.

oklahoma-question-776.title: Question 776
oklahoma-question-776.name: Amendment to Protect Death Penalty
oklahoma-question-776.description:
Question 776 is a sideways attempt to circumvent the traditional checks and balances of Oklahoma’s 3-branch system of government. It would add a section to the Oklahoma Constitution to define that the death penalty is not cruel and unusual punishment—a definition and role that is the province of Oklahoma’s courts. 

Question 776 would only open up the state to further costly legal challenges and disrupt several examinations into the state’s death penalty procedures.

oregon-measure-98.title: Measure 98
oregon-measure-98.name: Dropout Prevention and College Readiness Programs
oregon-measure-98.description:
Measure 98 would require the Oregon State Legislature to fund dropout-prevention and career and college readiness programs in Oregon high schools. 

High school students, especially those from low-income or rural backgrounds, often never learn about the wide array of paths available to them to lead a satisfying and well-paying career. Students who fall behind often aren’t provided the resources to help them turn their education around. 

Measure 98 does not create any new taxes or take away money from other programs. It directs new state revenue to three things: career tech education, college-level classes and high school dropout prevention.

The trajectory we put our students on in high school can often determine where they end up later in life. It’s up to use to promise bright futures for all students, especially those from underserved communities.

south-dakota-measure-22.title: Initiated Measure 22
south-dakota-measure-22.name: Anti-Corruption Act
south-dakota-measure-22.description:
If we are serious about restoring our democracy, we need to radically transform our campaign finance laws. 

Initiated Measure 22 would extensively address the issue of money in politics by holding politicians and lobbyists accountable. It would impose limits on contributions from PACs and campaign committees, requiring additional financial disclosures and creating an ethics commission to enforce campaign finance laws. The measure would create a publicly funded campaign finance program, allowing grassroots-supported candidates to fundraise competitively and limiting the influence of big money. The measure would also prohibit certain public officials from lobbying until two years after they leave their government position and place limitations on lobbyists’ gifts to state officials.

south-dakota-law-20.title: Referred Law 20
south-dakota-law-20.name: Create a Sub-Minimum Wage
south-dakota-law-20.description:
South Dakotans voted overwhelmingly for a minimum wage increase in 2014—a vote that Referred Law 20 (RL 20) would undercut by creating a “youth sub-minimum wage” for workers under 17 years old. 

RL 20 not only engages in a form of economic discrimination itself, it also opens the door to future age-based discrimination, including against the elderly. Legislators should not be able to overturn the will of the people by targeting vulnerable groups, like working teenagers who are unable to cast a ballot themselves. It is our responsibility to protect the next generations' rights and invest in their well-being. 

At a time when middle-class wages have been stagnant for decades, we should be raising the minimum wage, not decreasing it.

south-dakota-amendment-t.title: Amendment T
south-dakota-amendment-t.name: Redistricting Commission
south-dakota-amendment-t.description:
Voters should be choosing their politicians, but unfortunately, due to the biased process in which voting maps are drawn, it’s often politicians who choose their voters. When state legislators have the power to decide which voters are designated to particular voting districts, the result is often gerrymandering—maps are drawn to favor the incumbents and/or the party in charge.

Amendment T would address this by replacing the legislators on the map-drawing committee with voters—a move which not only reduces the bias in the process, but also saves taxpayer dollars. 

Committee members would not be allowed to hold public office 3 years before or after being selected and would ban the use of party identification to manipulate maps. The ultimate result is a fairer redistricting process and a healthier democracy.

virginia-right-to-work.title: Right to Work Amendment
virginia-right-to-work.name: Add Anti-Union Statute to Constitution
virginia-right-to-work.description:
Virginia currently has a right-to-work statute that is designed to weaken unions and, by effect, lower worker wages. The “Right to Work” Amendment would add right-to-work regulations to the Virginia Constitution to make these right-to-work regulations harder to change in the future. 

Attempts like these to codify legislation in the state constitution are little more than blatant attempts to shield legislators from having to debate and defend their positions. The reality is that right-to-work laws take away workers’ rights and drive down wages—that’s why billionaires like the Koch brothers heap millions in campaign donations to get them passed. 

Legislators need to be held accountable for their positions, especially when they stand against working families. That’s why we need to stop Virginia’s “Right to Work” Amendment in its tracks.

washington-initiative-1433.title: Initiative 1433
washington-initiative-1433.name: Washington Minimum Wage Increase
washington-initiative-1433.description:
Initiative 1433 (I-1433), the Washington Minimum Wage Increase, would and mandate employers to offer paid sick leave and raise Washington’s minimum wage to $13.50 by 2020. 

We can't grow our economy and create new jobs if people don't have enough money to buy products made and sold in their communities. Raising the minimum wage to a living wage is basic economic sense, and it leads to more productive workers, as well.

Almost every industrialized nation guarantees some sort of paid sick leave—with the United States being the exception. Not only is unethical to not guarantee paid sick leave to low wage workers, it creates an immense public health issue. I-1433 would help Washington lead the nation in taking a huge step forward for workers’ rights.
